thread.title: An Inspector Calls: A heavy price to pay to stay at The Vine House, Burnham Market, Norfolk (can £310 a night ever be worth it?)
thread.title_full: An Inspector Calls: A heavy price to pay to stay at The Vine House, Burnham Market, Norfolk (can £310 a night ever be worth it?) | Daily Mail Online

author: The Inspector
title: An Inspector Calls: A heavy price to pay to stay at The Vine House, Burnham Market, Norfolk (can £310 a night ever be worth it?)
text:
1
View
comments
Rating:
What do you expect for a room costing £310?
Perhaps a fully stocked mini-bar, especially when the bar and restaurant is down the road, some 100 yards away; perhaps a proper desk or at least somewhere to stand a laptop; perhaps a dimmer switch in the bathroom so you're not dazzled in the middle of the night; perhaps a light in the communal downstairs sitting room bright enough to read; a fire.
And peace and quiet instead of canned music.
Good, but worth the money? The Vine House is the stylish - but expensive - addition to The Hoste in Norfolk
No, we had none of the above. But then, this is pricey Burnham Market, North Norfolk's Georgian masterpiece that gets ritualistically defaced at weekends when the Range Rover brigade roars into town with Jack Wills-clad teenagers in the back and golden retrievers in the boot.
The Vine House is an annexe to The Hoste, which has been under new management for the past couple of years. It's a much quieter alternative to the main pub, which has morphed into a 62-room operation, buoyed by various associated businesses: holiday cottages; a converted railway station with seven further rooms; and a beauty spa.

Share this article Share No wonder there are three people manning reception at weekends.
The best part of this expanding empire is the original old bar at the front of the Hoste, and we love the main dining room next to it, with powder blue panelled walls and impressive works by local artists. There's no faulting the food and service either - as long as you're ready to pay £50 a head for a couple of courses and one bottle of wine.
We wake in the morning to discover the car has a flat. Reception does a brilliant job in organising down a repair while we tuck into the breakfast buffet in the Garden Room.
Some of us remember the Hoste Arms when it was just a simple pub. Mustn't obstruct progress and all that, but we can't help looking back with a dollop of nostalgia.
